bibl.title: Letter from Carlos J. Finlay to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 6, 1909

div1.p: Finlay informs Kean that nothing has turned up to lessen the belief that Cuba is free of yellow fever, and reports of personnel changes in Cuba's Sanitary Department. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Carlos J. Finlay to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 6, 1909
div1.opener:
80
Dr Charlos J. Finlay.
(Cuba's grand old man)
Havana, February 6 1909
Lieut. Colonel J.K. Kean U.S.A. M.c.
Surgeon-General's Office
Washington, D.C.
My dear Colonel
div1.p:
Please to excuse my writing in type for fear of
taxing too much your ingenuity in deciphering my scrawl and to
accept my apologies for not having gone on board to take leave of
Mrs. Kean and yourself the day of your departure, as I had intended,
owing to an indisposition of no consequence but which kept me sub-
sequently two days at home.

I hope you had a pleasant trip and are now once more comfort-
ably settled in your home.

You will be glad to know that nothing has turned up to lessen
our belief that we are really free from yellow-fever. Two cases report
ed as suspects in Santiago de Cuba have proved negative, and Doctor
Guiteras intends to send Dr. Agramonte and Lebredo to Oriente for a little
while to look carefully into the situation in that part of the Island.
The Sanitary Department has been much less subjected to wholesale
renewal of the personnel than other Departments, but the few that
have been changed are of vast importance. I refer to Barnet and Lopez
del Valle. The former has been given a position as Special Inspector
in the Secretary's Office while Lopez del Valle has changed places
with Dr. Rensoli as Chief of the Tuberculosis Dyspensary. Other changes
had been spoken of but somehow or other they have not been carried
into effect.

The inaugural session of the Junta Nacional de Sanidad y Beneficen
cia was held February 3d. I need not give you the names of the 13
active members of which it is composed as I suppose you already know
them, and the list has been published in most of our local papers. At
the second meeting, the following day, I was pleased tp observe that
in the course of the debate Dr. Alfredo Zayas supported with warmth
and free from any partisanship certain remarks made by Dr. Casuso in
opposition to the views maintained by the Secretary of the Departmt.

Feb. 7th. - I am informed that Dr. Claudio Delgado has been request-
ed to present his resignation, but has refused to do so stating that
he prefers to await his formal dismissal from the Service.

I have not seen Dr. Guiteras these last few days but I fear that
if he is to be deprived of valuable employees at the caprice of poli-
ticians he will find his position anything but a bed of roses, and
I cannot but congratulate myself for being out of the business, even
if I have to put up with certain privations which I knew were to be
expected. He will, I am sure, miss very much the valuable help that
Dr. Barnet would have given him, and although Dr. Rensoli is undoubted-
ly clever and bright he lacks the personal knowledge which Dr. Lopez
del Valle possesses of every nook and corner of the district of Havana
and his long experience in the Sanitary Department, having held res-
ponsible positions in it since Major Davis' time (1899).

Please to present my kindest regards to Mrs, Kean and believe
me, my dear Colonel,
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely Carlos J. Finlay Amistad n° 94 (Altos)
Habana.
